title: How is it legal for ISPs to provide less bandwidth than the advertised speed they are selling you? - Quora

response.answer_text: As far as I know, 100% of the time, ISPs provide speed offerings in bands with a disclaimer “up to” whatever they’re offering. Here’s the real deal: the economics of operating an ISP - of actually the entire Internet - is based on something called statistical multiplexing. You never, ever have a “guaranteed bandwidth connection” to anything - the data, both ways, is in packets. Those packets are sent over what at the time they’re sent looks like the “best path”. Shit happens. Paths go down or fill up - but that’s ok, because routing will replace them with alternate paths. Packets get damaged, lost, or discarded - but that’s OK, because the TCP retransmission protocols will replace them pretty quickly and the out-of-order reassembly protocols will smoothly insert them in place. Servers get overloaded - so there’s no place for your inbound packets to go, or they can’t move fast enough to queue up the outbound packets you’re looking for. That’s also ok, the protocols treat that like packet damage. All of this stuff is going on full-time, and it means that even if you were the only person actually using the Internet, it’s not possible to guarantee that you’ll get a specific performance. I spent a huge amount of timing studying this problem, and came up with a bunch of commercial implementations at Enron Broadband that let us offer actually guaranteed bandwidth to our customers - but only to other communications providers; the volumes at which you had to deal to make that feasible economically were far too vast for end-user customers. So what your brain tells you is that you signed up for “guaranteed 300mbps Internet” but what your eyes failed to see or your brain failed comprehend was the disclaimer that said “up to”. Because at the end user level? There’s no way to get guaranteed performance.

It is illegal in most countries of course. In some countries it may be perfectly OK since the law isn’t adheareed to for more important matters either, so who cares …. Hoever, commonly people do not read the service discription too well and this description often states that the service is “upto” rather than guaranteed. In fact, this may mean 2 things, 1. there may a level of sharing on their link between the Local Exchange and the data centres / backbone, which in the old days could be as much as 1:40 (before IPTV became a common service) and 2. their link to the infrastructure (i.e. the one from your home to the local exchange) uses a technology which maximum speed is depending on the wire plant quality and the distance between the LE and the customer. This may be overcome but there is potentially a signifficant cost involved to upgrade the wireplant and / or block capacity on the backbone for a customer. For consumer services it is also fact that the customer’s home cable or wifi infrastructure is often of poor quality, or poorly configured, and limiting the access capacity to the link.. so 100 Mbit is often just about right…. Then again, people are complaining about bandwidth but often it s merely a principle question since most computers cannot coop with sustained speeds over 100 Mbit or so anyway. Burst, OK but try to transfer a 10 GByte file. between your PC’s using your consumer router. You will definitively see some hickups due to all sorts of limiting factors like I/O busses, interrups, disk handling, Memory handling etc. immagine what it will be when trying this to the other side of the world… Next of course is asking the question why a residential consumer needs a dedicated 1000 Mbit link anyway (except for streaming sites etc.). To the best of my knowledge there is no commonly used application which utilises this kind of bandwidth except VOD and streaming platforms. However, a customer is in most countries protected agains suppliers which perform structurally below advertised levels. Proving this is and getting compensated is another thing since the above points rightfully provide plenty of handles for a lawyer to ensure the ISP gets away with complaints (for one, the ISP are often not the owner of the wireplant….). It would however be nice to have the ISP’s explain on their web site’s site calculations tools (where offered) what the estimated bandwidth is they have calculated for your location. It would surely be limiting the number of complaits. Over here this was done at some point in time. Not sure they all (still) do. I was told to expect 7 Mbit here and over time they improved a few things and I get about 15 now… so that is OK allthough the setup should support upto about 22 Mbit. In my case this is a matter of long distance to the LE. Just my 2 cents.
